awd_titl_txt: Police Investigator Decision Making in High Profile Cases
awd_abstract_narration:
Criminal investigations by law enforcement provide a critical aspect of the criminal justice process. Some investigations occur under the media spotlight, as high profile cases have the potential to exert public pressure on law enforcement as they conduct those investigations. While some high profile cases result in wrongful convictions, there is little scientific confirmation that wrongful convictions are more, or less, prevalent in high profile cases. This project will examine criminal investigations in the context of high profile cases, to determine whether a relationship exists between high profile crimes and wrongful convictions.

The project employs an experimental approach to examine how the psychological theory of confirmation bias comes into play in criminal investigations that take place under high media attention. It does so by analyzing whether confirmation bias is exacerbated in high profile criminal cases. Confirmation bias occurs when individuals subjectively interpret information in order to confirm their preexisting beliefs, often while ignoring, discrediting, or reinterpreting inconsistent information. High profile cases, where the media and the public exert pressure on the police to make an arrest, could have an effect on investigators' confirmation bias, which may further influence the possibility of a wrongful conviction when an innocent person is identified as the suspect. The experiments in this study will evaluate relations between confirmation bias, high profile cases, and wrongful convictions; as well, the project will investigate the influence of potential debiasing strategies. In this way, the project will examine confirmation bias in an investigative context, focusing on the role of high profile cases and innocence, as well as strategies to ameliorate confirmation bias.

por.por_cntn:
There were two aims to this project. First, to evaluate whether high profile cases strengthen investigators’ belief the suspect committed the crime, and the likelihood of wrongful conviction, when compared with low profile cases. We conducted two experiments to address the first aim. The first experiment asked law enforcement personnel to make decisions about a criminal case where the case was either high or low profile, with a suspect who was guilty or innocent. As part of this experiment, investigators conducted an interview with a mock suspect; these videos were used in the second experiment to evaluate whether case profile and guilt can affect third party observers’ perceptions of an interview. Ultimately, case profile (high vs. low) and the suspect’s guilt (guilty vs innocent) did not affect participants’ decisions about the case. There was one exception in the second experiment. Participants who watched a video with an innocent suspect believed that the investigator in that video thought the suspect was more likely to be guilty, compared to when the suspect was actually guilty. 

Our second aim was to evaluate whether beliefs in the suspect’s guilt can be altered by two debiasing techniques. The first technique is consider the opposite, where participants listed reasons why evidence in the case may – and may not – be reliable. The second technique is an accuracy motivation, where participants were told they would have to justify their decisions in the case. Neither technique altered participants’ belief that the suspect was guilty, or their judgments about the case. 

The intellectual merit of this project was to determine whether the belief a suspect is guilty is increased by high profile cases, or decreased by debiasing techniques. In all, our results indicate that an investigator’s belief the suspect is guilty is relatively stable across variations in the case (e.g., whether it is high profile) and variations in the activities participants did before making judgments about the case (e.g., debiasing techniques). 

The broader impact of this project was to better understand investigative decision-making and the role of an investigators’ belief in the suspect’s guilt. Specifically, whether the belief the suspect is guilty could affect someone else’s judgment about the case. Our results showed that observers believed an interviewer thought the suspect was more likely to be guilty, when in fact he was innocent. This aligns with previous research indicating that factually innocent people can experience more coercive interrogations than those who are guilty (Kassin et al., 2003). In addition, our results help to shed light on investigative decisions that can lead to false confessions, which in turn, can lead to wrongful convictions.
